member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase
member.summary:
Represents the common implementation of the protocol independent definition of any kind of data that can be parsed or generated.
This is the base class of all parsing/generating classes in the phasor protocols library; it is the root of the parsing/generating class hierarchy.
member.remarks: This base class represents data images for parsing or generation in terms of a header, body and footer (see for details).

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.Attributes
member.summary: Gets a of string based property names and values for this object.
member.remarks: The attributes dictionary is relevant to all channel properties. This dictionary will only be instantiated with a call to the Attributes property which will begin the enumeration of relevant system properties. This is typically used for display purposes. For example, this information is displayed in a tree view on the PMU Connection Tester to display attributes of data elements that may be protocol specific.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.BinaryImage
member.summary: Gets the binary image of the object.
member.remarks: This property is not typically overridden since it is the combination of the header, body and footer images.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.BodyImage
member.summary: Gets the binary body image of the object.
member.remarks: This property is typically overridden by a specific protocol implementation.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.FooterImage
member.summary: Gets the binary footer image of the object.
member.remarks: This property is typically overridden by a specific protocol implementation.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1
member.summary: Represents the protocol independent common implementation of any frame of data that can be sent or received.

remarks.para: This phasor protocol implementation defines a "frame" as a collection of cells (logical units of data). For example, a could be defined as a PMU within a frame of data, a (derived from ), that contains multiple PMU's coming from a PDC.
This class implements the interface so it can be cooperatively integrated into measurement concentration. For more information see the class.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Creates a new from serialization parameters.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1.#ctor(System.UInt16,Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IChannelCellCollection{`0},Gemstone.Ticks)
member.summary: Creates a new from specified parameters.
member.param: The reference to the collection of cells for this .
The exact timestamp, in , of the data represented by this .

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1.AllowQueuedPublication
member.summary: Gets flag that determines if frame image can be queued for publication or should be processed immediately.
member.remarks: Some frames, e.g., a configuration or key frame, may be critical to processing of other frames. In this case, these types of frames should be published immediately so that subsequent frame parsing can have access to needed critical information. All other frames are assumed to be queued by default.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1.AppendChecksum(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Appends checksum onto starting at .
member.param: Buffer image on which to append checksum.
Index into where checksum should be appended.
member.remarks: Default implementation encodes checksum in big-endian order and expects buffer size large enough to accommodate 2-byte checksum representation. Override method if protocol expectations are different.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags
member.summary: Protocol independent common status flags enumeration.

remarks.para: These flags are expected to exist in the high-word of a double-word flag set such that original word flags remain in-tact in low-word of double-word flag set.

Note that value being stored in a historian using a 32-bit single precision floating number value will only have castable conversion accuracy back to an unsigned 32-bit integer up to the 24th bit, so any bits used beyond Bit23 will be lossy.

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataModified
member.summary: Data was modified by a post-processing device, e.g., a PDC (0 for no modifications, 1 when data modified).

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataDiscarded
member.summary: Data was discarded from real-time stream due to late arrival (0 when not discarded, 1 when discarded).

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataIsValid
member.summary: Data is valid (0 when device data is valid, 1 when invalid or device is in test mode).

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.SynchronizationIsValid
member.summary: Synchronization is valid (0 when in device is in sync, 1 when it is not).

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataSortingType
member.summary: Data sorting type, 0 by timestamp, 1 by arrival.

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DeviceError
member.summary: Device error (including configuration error), 0 when no error.

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.ReservedFlags
member.summary: Reserved bits for future common flags, presently set to 0.

member.name: F:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.FrameParserBase`1
member.summary: Represents a frame parser that defines the basic functionality for a protocol to parse a binary data stream and return the parsed data via events.
member.typeparam: Frame type identifier used to distinguish frames.
member.remarks:
Frame parsers are implemented as a write-only streams so that data can come from any source.
See for more detail. Note that using the multi-source frame image parser base allows buffers to come in from different channels and still be parsed correctly.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.FrameParserBase`1.RedundantFramesPerPacket
member.summary: Gets the number of redundant frames in each packet.

remarks.para: This value is used when calculating statistics. It is assumed that for each frame that is received, that frame will be included in the next n packets, where n is the number of redundant frames per packet.
This base class returns 0, as most protocols do not support redundant frames.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IChannelFrame
member.summary: Represents a protocol independent interface representation of any kind of frame of data that contains a collection of objects.

remarks.para: The phasor protocols library defines a "frame" as a collection of cells (logical units of data). For example, a would be defined as a PMU within a frame of data, a (derived from ), that contains multiple PMU's coming from a PDC.
This interface inherits so that classes implementing this interface can be cooperatively integrated into measurement concentration (see ).

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser
member.summary: Protocol independent frame parser.
member.remarks: This class takes all protocol frame parsing implementations and reduces them to a single simple-to-use class exposing all data through abstract interfaces (e.g., IConfigurationFrame, IDataFrame, etc.) - this way new protocol implementations can be added without adversely affecting consuming code. Additionally, this class implements a variety of transport options (e.g., TCP, UDP, Serial, etc.) and hides the complexities of this connectivity and internally pushes all data received from the selected transport protocol to the selected phasor parsing protocol.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.ConfigurationFrameVersion
member.summary: Gets or sets specific configuration frame version to request from device which overrides default that otherwise requests latest configuration frame version for current protocol.

remarks.para: If user selects IEEE C37.118-2011 protocol, this will default to requesting a configuration frame 3 frame. If remote device does not support this, this property can be set to send a configuration frame 2 frame instead.
This property can be assigned as a connection string parameter, e.g.: configurationFrameVersion=2 or configurationFrameVersion=SendConfigurationFrame2

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.CalculatePower(Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue,Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue)
member.summary: Calculates watts from imaginary and real components of a voltage and current phasor.
member.returns: Calculated watts from imaginary and real components of specified and phasors.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.CalculateVars(Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue,Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue)
member.summary: Calculates vars (total volt-amperes of reactive power) from imaginary and real components of a voltage and current phasor.
member.returns: Calculated vars (total volt-amperes of reactive power) from imaginary and real components of specified and phasors.
member.remarks: Although the units class technically represents watts (i.e., real power) and vars (i.e., imaginary power) are properly expressed in volt-amperes reactive (VAr), the calculated result is still a representation of power and therefore the units class is used to express the return value leaving the consumer to properly apply the needed engineering units for display purposes.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.BPAPDCstream.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.BPAPDCstream.FrameParser.ParseWordCountFromByte
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that interprets word count in packet header from a byte instead of a word.
member.remarks: Set to true to interpret word count in packet header from a byte instead of a word - if the sync byte (0xAA) is at position one, then the word count would be interpreted from byte four. Some older BPA PDC stream implementations have a 0x01 in byte three where there should be a 0x00 and this throws off the frame length, setting this property to true will correctly interpret the word count.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.FNET.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.CommandFrame
member.summary: Represents the IEC 61850-90-5 implementation of a that can be sent or received.
member.remarks: IEC 61850-90-5 command frames are designed only to be sent to a device, not received from a device. As a result this frame does not implement for automated frame parsing. This class exposes a constructor that accepts a binary image in order to manually parse a command frame.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.CommandFrame.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new from the given .
member.param: Start index into to begin parsing.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by a consumer to parse a received IEC 61850-90-5 command frame. Typically command frames are sent to a device. This constructor would used if this code was being used inside of a phasor measurement device.
member.exception: is not large enough to parse frame.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.DigitalDefinition.GetLabel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.
member.returns: A value of the label corresponding to the parameter.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEEE1344.CommandFrame
member.summary: Represents the IEEE 1344 implementation of a that can be sent or received.
member.remarks: IEEE 1344 command frames are designed only to be sent to a device, not received from a device. As a result this frame does not implement for automated frame parsing. This class exposes a constructor that accepts a binary image in order to manually parse a command frame.

member.summary: Creates a new from the given .
member.param: Start index into to begin parsing.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by a consumer to parse a received IEEE 1344 command frame. Typically command frames are sent to a device. This constructor would used if this code was being used inside of a phasor measurement device.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEEE1344.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEEE1344.FrameParser.ProtocolUsesSyncBytes
member.summary: Gets flag that determines if this protocol parsing implementation uses synchronization bytes.
member.remarks: The IEEE 1344 protocol does not use synchronization bytes, as a result this property returns false.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.DigitalDefinition.GetLabel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.
member.returns: A value of the label corresponding to the parameter.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.DataFrame.AppendChecksum(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Appends checksum onto starting at .
member.param: Buffer image on which to append checksum.
Index into where checksum should be appended.
member.remarks: Default implementation encodes checksum in big-endian order and expects buffer size large enough to accommodate 2-byte checksum representation. We override this method since checksum in Macrodyne is a single byte.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.HeaderFrame.AppendChecksum(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Appends checksum onto starting at .
member.param: Buffer image on which to append checksum.
Index into where checksum should be appended.
member.remarks: Default implementation encodes checksum in big-endian order and expects buffer size large enough to accommodate 2-byte checksum representation. We override this method since checksum in Macrodyne is a single byte.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PhasorProtocols.SelFastMessage.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.
